questions.question: Which of the following gross motor milestones would you expect to see in a 3-year-old child?
questions.explanation: A 3-year-old child is expected to have developed certain gross motor skills, including walking upstairs with alternate feet.

questions.question: You notice a child pulling to the standing position and then shuffling around by holding onto furniture. At what age is this milestone typically attained?
questions.explanation: Cruising is an activity in which a child pulls to the standing position and then shuffles around holding onto a piece of furniture. Cruising is attained by 10-11 months.

questions.question: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby, totally occupied with his little game and a mother trying hard to spoon-feed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6. What is the likely age that this milestone corresponds to?
questions.explanation: A child can usually make a tower of 6 blocks by 24 months. A child makes a tower of: 2 blocks by 15 months, 3 blocks by 18 months, 6 blocks by 2 years, and 9 blocks by 3 years.

questions.question: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained?
questions.explanation: The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger. Developmental progression of the grasp: • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp). • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger. • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

questions.question: A final-year medical student is examining a baby in the ward. As the infant is pulled to sit, he notices a head lag. By what age should this infant ideally start to hold his head steady without any bobbing motion?
questions.explanation: An infant can hold his head steady when pulled to sit, without head bobbing, by the age of 4 months. Regarding head steadiness: • Up till 2 months of age, there is a significant head lag when the infant is pulled to sit. • At 3 months, head lag is partially compensated but still present; the infant attains early head control with bobbing motion and sits with back rounded. • At 4 months, there is no head lag when pulled to sit and the infant sits with full truncal support.

questions.question: Your sister tells you that your nephew has now started using his crayons. He easily copies circles, but still has trouble with squares. Other than a minor ASD noted incidentally at birth, he is a perfectly healthy child. Which of the following would you expect him to be able to do at this stage?
questions.explanation: Normally, a child is able to copy a circle at 3 years and a square at 4 years. This child is a 3-year-old, and he should be able to know his name and gender. A child is able to tell a story at 4 years. A child asks the meaning of words at 5 years. A child can skip at 5 years.

questions.question: Match the following milestones with the corresponding age.
questions.explanation: Handedness is established during the 3rd year (24 to 36 months). Taste perception is present since birth. Monosyllabic babble is seen at 6 months. Response to faces and voices with a smile is seen at 1.5 months. The child creeps upstairs by 15 months.

questions.question: You are taking a detailed history from the parents of a child with a suspected autism spectrum disorder. Parents are worried that their child does not smile or maintain eye contact and is not interested in toys. At what ages should a typical child exhibit a 'social smile' and 'stranger anxiety'?
questions.explanation: Social smile is typically seen at 2 months and stranger anxiety at 6 months. Social smile: At 1 month of age, a child smiles involuntarily. At 2 months of age, social smile develops; that is, the child smiles voluntarily and reciprocally, in response to someone else's smile. Stranger anxiety: Before 6 months, the child is sociable and friendly even with strangers. At 6 months, there is an onset of stranger anxiety; infants look back and forth between an approaching stranger and parent and may cling or cry anxiously.

questions.question: A pediatrician is evaluating a toddler for mental retardation. She hands a bright red ball to the baby and lets him play with it. She then takes the ball and hides it under a blanket in front of him. The child confusedly stares at the blanket and cries instead of searching for it. What is being tested here?
questions.explanation: Understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen is called object permanence. This is due to an ability to form a mental representation of the object. It is attained at the age of 8-9 months. Option A: Separation anxiety begins at about 9 months of age. Children wake up crying from their naps as they realize that their parents are not in the same room as them. This is different from stranger anxiety displayed by the child at the age of 6-7 months, wherein they react to approaching strangers by crying or clinging to their parent. Option B: A transitional object is an object, such as a blanket or a stuffed toy, that is used by many children as a symbol of the absent parent. It is seen at around 18 months. Option C: Symbolic transformations in play: At 12 months - make-believe (symbolic) play centres on the child's own body, e.g., the child pretends to drink from an empty cup. At 18 months - symbolic transformations in play are not limited to the child's body, e.g., a doll can be fed from a plate.

questions.question: Parents of a 9-month-old infant, with a history of preterm delivery and prolonged NICU stay, are concerned that the child is lagging behind in his milestones. You would suspect a developmental delay in this child if his developmental quotient (DQ) is below
questions.explanation: A developmental delay should be suspected if the development quotient (DQ) is below 70%. It is calculated as: DQ = Developmental age x 100 / Chronological age. From the highest milestones achieved by the child, the developmental age in a particular domain is calculated. The chronological age is the actual age in term babies. However, in preterm infants, a corrected age rather than postnatal age is used till two years of age. This is used to account for the small gap in neurological development that premature children have yet to catch up. For example, a child born at 32 weeks gestation (gestational age) seen at 12 weeks of age (postnatal age), should be considered as a 4-week-old (corrected age) child. If there is a delay (DQ < 70%) in more than 2 domains, then global developmental delay (GDD) is suspected.

questions.question: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear, that he reaches outto with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved?
questions.explanation: The earliest age of appearance of bidextrous reach is 4 months.Fine motor reflexes begin to appear only after the palmar grasp reflex disappears at 3-4months. The development of unidextrous reach occurs by 6 months of age.

questions.question: A child was able to count 4 pennies but was unable to name 4 colors. The probable age of thechild is
questions.explanation: A 4-year-old child can count 4 pennies but cannot name 4 colours. A child can name 4 colours at 5years of age.Note:An easy way to remember this:• No. of objects counted = age• No. of colours identified = age - 1

questions.question: A term, 4-month-old infant, is developing normally. By what age do you expect her to walkwithout support and use polysyllabic jargon?
questions.explanation: A 15-month-old child can walk without support and use polysyllabic jargon.Walking: A child begins to cruise at 10 months, walk with support at 12 months, and walk withoutsupport at 15 months.Jargon is seen around 15 months of age. It is a pre-linguistic vocalization in which the childbabbles using strings of word-like sounds and produces words that do not make much sense toothers.

questions.question: One of the kids has scribbled all over a newly painted wall inside an Anganwadi. You notice there are some triangles and squares as well, in this drawing. This child must be older than
questions.explanation: The milestones at 5 years of age are: • Motor - skips • Adaptive draws triangle • Language - asks meaning of words, names 4 colors • Social - dresses and undresses

questions.question: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called asdevelopmental delay?
questions.explanation: Feeding by spoon is a social milestone that typically appears by 18 months. If this is absent, thenthe child should be termed as having a developmental delay. Hopping on one leg, drawing asquare, and passing a ball to someone appear by 48 months of age.Red flag signs in developmental screening and surveillance are indicators that suggest a seriousdisorder in a child's development, requiring referral to a pediatrician. These are given below:Positive indicators: Presence of any of the following• Loss of developmental skills at any age•Concerns about vision or confirmed visual impairment80• Hearing loss at any age• Persistently low muscle tone•• Lack of speech by 18 months without other means of communication• Asymmetry of movements or features suggestive of cerebral palsy• Persistent toe walking• Complex disabilities• Unusual head circumference compared to norms• Clinician uncertainty about the developmental disorder.Negative Indicators:• Inability to sit unsupported by 12 monthsInability to walk by 18 months in boys or 2 years in girls.• Inability to walk normally••Inability to run by 2.5 yearsInability to hold objects in hand by 5 months or reach for them by 6 months.• Inability to point at objects to share interest by 2 years

questions.question: After assessing a young child treated for unilateral retinoblastoma, you note significant delaysin the cognitive and fine motor domains. The baby can stand without support and creep well.Normally, the highest fine motor skill a baby of this age is expected to have is
questions.explanation: A baby that stands without support is most likely to be 12 months. The highest fine motor skill sheis expected to have is mature pincer grasp (12 months).Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months. Immature pincer graspis seen at 9 months. Child begins to scribble after 15 months.Fine motor development is critically linked with hand-eye coordination. Children who havedisease-related loss of vision in early infancy develop difficulties in visuomotor integration andlags behind in fine motor milestones.

questions.question: You are a pediatrics resident handling the well-child clinic for the week and you are teachingundergraduates how to do a simple developmental assessment. A preterm baby born at 32weeks, is brought in for a follow-up visit at 6 months. What is the age you would ask thestudents to assume when undertaking developmental assessment in this child?
questions.explanation: The corrected age (in weeks) to be assumed while undertaking developmental assessment is 16weeks.Corrected age (in weeks) = (Gestational age + postnatal age) - 40 weeksIn this case, since the baby is born 8 weeks preterm, the 8 weeks of intrauterine growth anddevelopment she missed, is accounted for post-natally. Thus, for assessing the correctdevelopmental age, 8 weeks has to be subtracted from the chronological age.In babies born preterm, corrected age is used for their developmental assessment until 2 years ofage.81

questions.question: 73A young infant is brought to you with a suspected developmental delay. The child is intentlylooking at his own hands. You would consider referring this child to a specialist if thismilestone persists after
questions.explanation: Between 12 and 20 weeks, the child observes his own hands very intently. This milestone is calledhand regard and it should disappear by 20 weeks. Its persistence after 20 weeks is consideredabnormal.In a blind child, however, it may persist beyond 20 weeks normally and is called apparent handregard.82
